name: Common Meeting - Translation
description: A practical deck for common phrases used in technical meetings, covering attendance, understanding issues, and general communication in both Spanish and English.

cards.sideA: El no va a venir a la reunion, tenia cosas personales que hacer.

sideB.text: He's not going to make it to the meeting. He had some personal stuff to take care of.
He won't be able to join today. He had a personal matter to attend to.
He's going to miss the meeting; he had something personal come up.
He won't join the meeting; he had to take care of a personal matter.
He's not coming to the meeting. He had personal things to do.
He's not coming to the meeting. He had personal stuff to do.

cards.note:
**[16]**

Phrasal verbs like [to make it to] (attend) and [to take care of] (deal with) are common.

~things to make~ is incorrect; the verb make is for creating. For tasks, use [do] or [take care of].

~To assist~ is a false friend meaning 'to help'. The correct verb is [to attend].

cards.sideA: La verdad no se si el vaya a venir a la reunion.

sideB.text: To be honest, I'm not sure if he's going to join the meeting.
I actually don't know if he'll make it to the meeting.
Honestly, I'm not sure if he'll be there.
To be honest, I don't know if he's coming to the meeting.

cards.note:
**[46]**

'La verdad' translates idiomatically to [To be honest] or [Honestly], not the literal ~The true~.

After 'if', you need a proper future tense, such as [if he will go] or [if he is going to go], not ~if he go~.

cards.sideA: Le voy a preguntar si es que el vendra a la reunion.

sideB.text: I'm going to ask him if he's coming to the meeting.
I'll check with him to see if he'll be joining us.
I'll find out if he's planning to attend the meeting.

cards.note:
**[46]**

The Spanish phrase 'si es que' translates to just [if]. The word ~that~ in ~if that he will come~ is unnecessary.

The structure ~I will ask him will he come~ is incorrect. After 'ask him', use [if] followed by a standard sentence structure: [if he will come].

cards.sideA: Sí vendra a la reunion, esta en camino.

sideB.text: Yes, he's coming to the meeting. He's on his way.
Yep, he'll be here. He's on his way.
He'll be at the meeting. He's on his way.
He'll join the meeting. He's on his way.

cards.note:
The correct idiom for traveling towards a destination is [on the way]. The phrase ~in the way~ means something is an obstacle.

The verb [join] does not need the preposition to. The correct form is [join the meeting], not ~join to the meeting~.

cards.sideA: Sí, yo voy a venir a la reunion que hay más tarde.

sideB.text: Yes, I'll be at the meeting later on.
Yep, I'm going to join the meeting later.
I'll make it to the meeting later.
Yes, I'm coming to the meeting later.
Yes, I'll join the meeting later.

cards.note:
**[27]**

The phrase 'que hay más tarde' is naturally expressed as just [later] or [later on], not the literal ~that there is later~.

Use [attend] or [join], not ~assist~. Also, ~more late~ is incorrect; the correct adverb is [later].

~I'll come the meeting~ (Incorrect: The verb 'come' requires the preposition 'to' when followed by a destination. Correct: 'come TO the meeting'.)

cards.sideA: No podre asistir a la reunion de mañana.

sideB.text: I won't be able to make it to tomorrow's meeting.
I can't attend the meeting tomorrow.
Unfortunately, I won't be able to attend the meeting tomorrow.
I won't be able to join the meeting tomorrow.
I can't join the meeting tomorrow.

cards.note:
**[19]**

The modal verb can does not have a future form; I will not can is incorrect. You must use the structure [will be able to].

~Assist~ is a false friend for 'asistir'; use [attend]. The possessive form [tomorrow's meeting] is more natural than the meeting of tomorrow.

cards.sideA: No podre asistir a la reunion de más tarde.

sideB.text: I won't be able to join the meeting later.
I can't make it to the meeting later on.
I won't be able to be there for the meeting later.
I can't join the meeting later.

cards.note:
**[27]**

Negatives are formed with [not] (e.g., [I cannot] or [I can't]), not ~I no can~.

~More late~ is grammatically incorrect; use [later].

cards.sideA: El no podra asistir a la reunion de mañana.

sideB.text: He won't be able to attend tomorrow's meeting.
He can't make it to the meeting tomorrow.
He isn't going to be at the meeting tomorrow.
He won't be able to join the meeting tomorrow.
He won't join the meeting tomorrow.
He can't join the meeting tomorrow.

cards.note:
**[17]**

Assist is a false friend; it means 'to help'. The correct verb is [attend].

~He won't join to the meeting~ (Incorrect preposition. The verb 'join' directly takes an object and does not need 'to'. The correct form is [join the meeting].)

cards.sideA: Sí, podre unirme a la reunion.

sideB.text: Yes, I'll be able to join the meeting.
Yep, I can make it to the meeting.
Yes, I'll be there.
Yes, I can join the meeting.

cards.note:
**[19]**

You cannot combine will and can. The correct structure for future ability is [will be able to].

After the modal verb [can], the next verb is used in its base form without to. Correct: [I can join], not I can to join.

cards.sideA: No, no podre unirme a la reunion pasado mañana.

sideB.text: No, I won't be able to join the meeting the day after tomorrow.
No, I can't make it to the meeting the day after tomorrow.
Unfortunately, I won't be available for the meeting the day after tomorrow.

cards.note:
[The day after tomorrow] is the standard way to express 'pasado mañana'. ~Passed tomorrow~ is not a correct time expression.

Double error: ~won't can~ is incorrect (use [won't be able to]), and ~join to~ is incorrect (use [join]).

cards.sideA: Sí podre unirme a la reunion el viernes.

sideB.text: Yes, I'll be able to join the meeting on Friday.
Yep, I can make it to the meeting on Friday.
Yes, I'm available for the meeting on Friday.
Yes, I can join the meeting on Friday.

cards.note:
**[21]**
The Spanish 'Si' (no accent) means 'if', but 'Sí' (with accent) means 'yes'. Don't confuse If I can join... with [Yes, I can join...].

We don't use the before days of the week in this context; it's [on Friday].

cards.sideA: El no podra unirse a la reunion el jueves.

sideB.text: He won't be able to join the meeting on Thursday.
He can't make it to the meeting on Thursday.
He isn't available for the meeting on Thursday.

cards.note:
The correct negative of 'can' is [cannot] or [can't], not ~no can~.

The structure ~is not able for join~ is incorrect. The adjective 'able' requires the 'to-infinitive' form: [is not able TO join].

cards.sideA: Me queda bastante claro el problema.

sideB.text: The issue is pretty clear to me now.
Yeah, I have a clear understanding of the issue.
I understand the problem clearly now.
It's clear to me.

cards.note:
The literal translation The problem stays clear to me is unnatural. English uses [The problem is clear to me] or [I understand].

Starting with For me... For me the problem is very clear is less natural than starting with the subject ([The problem is...]) or the person ([I understand...]).

~It's clear to me the issue.~ (Unnatural sentence structure. It is better to place the subject first: 'The issue is clear to me'.)

cards.sideA: Sí, entendi el problema.

sideB.text: Yep, I get the issue.
Got it. I understand the problem.
Yes, I understand the issue.
Yeah, I got the issue.

cards.note:
[Got it] is a very common and concise way to confirm understanding.

Using the present tense ([understand] or [get]) is more natural to express your current state of knowledge than the simple past (I understood).

~Comprehend~ is a very formal word; in conversation, [understand] or [get] is better.

~Yes, I understood the issue.~ (While grammatically correct, using the simple past 'understood' can imply that you understood it at a specific point in the past. For immediate confirmation in a conversation, 'I understand' or 'I get it' is super more natural.)

cards.sideA: Estoy tomando apuntes sobre los problemas.

sideB.text: I'm taking notes on the issues.
I'm writing down the main points about these bugs.
I'm jotting down the details of the problems.
I'm taking notes about the issues.

cards.note:
**[18]**

The correct English phrase is [taking notes]. Taking points is not a standard idiom.

[Annotate] means to add notes to a specific text or diagram. For general note-taking during a conversation, [taking notes] is the correct expression.

cards.sideA: No me ha quedado del todo claro el problema, podrias refrasearlo porfavor.

sideB.text: I'm not sure I fully understand the issue. Could you please rephrase it?
The issue isn't totally clear to me yet. Can you explain it in a different way?
I don't think I quite follow. Could you word that differently, please?
I didn't understand the problem very well, can you rephrase it?
I didn't understand the problem really well, can you rephrase it?

cards.note:
The literal translation The problem has not stayed clear for me is unnatural. Focus on the person: [I don't understand] or [It isn't clear to me].

The single verb for 'decir con otras palabras' is [to rephrase]. The request [Could you rephrase it?] is natural and polite.

Using [really well] is a common and slightly more informal alternative to [very well].

cards.sideA: No entendi muy bien el problema, puedes repetirlo?

sideB.text: I didn't quite get the issue. Could you repeat that?
Sorry, I missed that. Can you go over the problem again?
I'm a bit lost, could you run that by me one more time?
I didn't understand that very well. Could you repeat it?
I didn't understand the issue really well. Could you repeat it?

cards.note:
The negative past tense requires [did not] or [didn't], not I not understood. Correct: [I didn't understand].

~Good~ is an adjective. The correct adverb to modify a verb like 'understand' is [well]. Correct: [I didn't understand it well].

~I didn't understand really well the issue.~ (Awkward word order. It is more natural to place the adverbial phrase 'really well' after the object: 'I didn't understand the issue really well'.)

cards.sideA: Le preguntare a Mario acerca del problema.

sideB.text: I'll ask Mario about the issue.
I'm going to touch base with Mario regarding this bug.
I'll check with Mario about the problem.

cards.note:
The verb [ask] doesn't require the preposition ~to~. Correct: [I will ask Mario], not ~I will ask to Mario~.

The structure is [consult with someone ABOUT something]. ~Consult with Mario the problem~ is incorrect.

cards.sideA: Estamos trabajando aun en el problema.

sideB.text: We're still working on the issue.
The issue is still in progress.
We are actively working to resolve the problem.

cards.note:
**[24]**

~Yet~ is typically used in negative sentences or questions. For affirmative sentences meaning 'todavía', use [still].

The literal ~We are in the work of the problem~ is incorrect. The natural way to express this is with the verb [working on] or the phrase [in progress].

cards.sideA: Sí, estamos trabajando en el problema, pero necesitamos algo mas de tiempo.

sideB.text: Yes, we're working on the issue, but we need a bit more time.
That's right. We're on it, but we'll need some extra time.
We are making progress on the problem, but we require a little more time.

cards.note:
A direct translation of 'algo más de tiempo' like something more of time is incorrect. Use the idiom [a bit more time] or [some more time].

The word order we need more time something is incorrect. Phrases like [a bit] or [a little] come before 'more time'.

~we need a bit of more time~ (Incorrect idiom. The preposition 'of' is not used here. The correct phrase is [a bit more time] or [a little more time].)

cards.sideA: El problema ya ha sido solucionado.

sideB.text: The issue has already been fixed.
The problem has been resolved.
The problem is solved.
The problem is already fixed.

cards.note:
**[12]**

The word [already] usually goes between the auxiliary and main verb, as in [has already been solved], not already was solved.

~Solutioned~ is not a standard English verb. The correct verbs are [solved], [fixed], or [resolved].

~The problem have been resolved.~ (Incorrect subject-verb agreement. The subject 'The problem' is singular, so it requires the singular verb 'has', not 'have'.)

cards.sideA: El fix del problema sera entregado en el proximo release.

sideB.text: The fix for this issue will be delivered in the next release.
The fix is scheduled for the next release.
The solution for this problem will be included in the upcoming release.

cards.note:
**[12]**

After [will be], you need the past participle for the passive voice. Delivery is a noun; [delivered] is the correct verb form.

While given isn't strictly wrong, [delivered] or [included] are more professional terms in a software context.

~The fix of this issue will be delivered for the next release.~ (Slightly unnatural: Use the preposition 'for' to link a solution to a problem, e.g., 'fix FOR this issue'. Use 'in' to specify when something is included within a release, e.g., 'delivered IN the next release'.)

 ~The fix of this issue~, suena un poco raro y no es la forma estándar. La opción correcta y mucho más común es [The fix for this issue]. 
Usamos of más para indicar posesión, 
Usamos for para indicar el propósito de algo.

cards.sideA: ¿Que tipo de cuenta has usado para obtener ese problema?

sideB.text: What kind of account did you use to get that issue?
Which account type did you use when you ran into this bug?
What were the account details you used to reproduce the problem?
What kind of account have you used to get that issue?

cards.note:
**[50]**

English questions with 'what' require an auxiliary verb like [did] before the subject: [did you use...?], not ~you used...?~.

~Obtain a problem~ is too formal and literal. In the context of bugs, you [get], [find], or [run into] them.

cards.sideA: ¿Podrias compartir la cuenta que has usado para poder replicar el problema?

sideB.text: Could you share the account you used so I can replicate the issue?
Can you send me the credentials for the account you used? I need them to reproduce the bug.
Would you be able to provide the account info? I'd like to try and replicate the issue on my end.
Could you share the account you've used so I can replicate the issue?

cards.note:
The correct structure is [share something WITH someone]. ~Share me the account~ is incorrect.

To express purpose, use the structure [to replicate] or [so I can replicate], not ~for can replicate~.

cards.sideA: Usando mis cuentas no he podido obtener ese problema.

sideB.text: I haven't been able to replicate the issue using my accounts.
I couldn't reproduce that bug with my test accounts.
I tried with my accounts, but I couldn't get the problem to occur.
Using my accounts, I haven't been able to get the issue.
I haven't got that issue using my account.

cards.note:
The present perfect [haven't] must be followed by a past participle, like [been able to], not a modal verb like can.

The negative form of 'could' is [could not] or [couldn't], not not could. Also, obtain the problem is unnatural; use [get the issue].

cards.sideA: ¿Pueden ver mi pantalla?

sideB.text: Can you all see my screen?
Let me know if you can see my screen.
Is my screen sharing correctly?

cards.note:
~To look~ is an active action; the correct verb for passive perception here is [to see].

~You can see my screen?~ is a statement. To form a question, the modal verb [can] must come before the subject [you]: [Can you see...?]

cards.sideA: ¿Qué opinan sobre esto?

sideB.text: What are your thoughts on this?
What do you guys think about this?
Any feedback on this part?
What's your opinion about this?
What are your thoughts about this?

cards.note:
**[50]**

Questions with 'what' require the auxiliary verb [do] before the subject: [What do you think...?], not What you think?.

~How~ asks about the manner/method. [What] asks for the opinion itself. To ask for an opinion, use [What do you think?].

cards.sideA: Se te escucha un poco entrecortado.

sideB.text: You're breaking up a little bit.
Your audio is a little choppy.
We're losing you, your connection seems unstable.
It sounds like you're breaking up a bit.
It sounds a bit cut off.

cards.note:
The literal translation You listen cut is incorrect. The correct idiom is [You're breaking up] or [Your audio is choppy].

~I hear you a bit cut off~ (While understandable, this is not a common idiom. Native speakers would say 'You're breaking up' or 'Your audio is choppy'. 'Cut off' usually means the connection was lost completely.)

cards.sideA: Estás en silencio / mute.

sideB.text: I think you're on mute.
You might be muted.
We can't hear you, can you check if you're muted?

cards.note:
~In silence~ means there is no noise in the environment. To describe a microphone being off, use the specific term [on mute] or [muted].

~Mute~ is not something you 'have'. It is a state you are 'in' or 'on'. Correct: [You are on mute].

cards.sideA: Sí, me parece una buena idea.

sideB.text: Yeah, that sounds like a good idea.
I agree, that makes sense.
That's a great approach, I'm on board.
It seems like a good idea.

cards.note:
The verb seem doesn't use the structure ~it seems me~. Correct forms are [It seems like a good idea TO ME] or, more naturally, [That sounds like a good idea].

[Agree] is a verb, not an adjective. You don't say ~I am agree~. The correct form is [I agree].

~It seems a good idea to me~ (Slightly unnatural: It's more common and idiomatic to include 'like', e.g., 'It seems LIKE a good idea to me'. The phrase 'That sounds like a good idea' is even more common.)

cards.sideA: Yo me encargo de eso.

sideB.text: I can take care of that.
I'll handle it.
Leave it with me, I'll get it done.
I'll handle that.

cards.note:
The literal translation I charge of that is incorrect. The correct idiom is [I'm in charge of that] (for responsibility) or, for taking on a task, [I'll handle it].

~I make me charge of that~ is an incorrect structure. English doesn't use a reflexive verb here.

~I'll handle on that. / I'll handle of that.~ (Incorrect. The verb 'handle' is transitive and does not take a preposition like 'on' or 'of'. The correct form is 'I'll handle it'.)

cards.sideA: Entonces, para resumir...

sideB.text: So, to recap...
Alright, just to summarize the key points...
Let me quickly go over what we've decided.
So, to summarize...

cards.note:
**[17]**

Resume is a verb ('to start again') or a noun (a CV). The verb for 'resumir' is [to summarize] or [to recap].

~To make a summary~ is grammatically okay but clunky. Using the verbs [to summarize] or [to recap] is more direct and natural.

~So, to summary...~ (Incorrect: 'summary' is a noun. The infinitive verb form is required here, which is 'to summarize'.)

cards.sideA: Podemos revisar ese tema después para no desviarnos.

sideB.text: Let's take that offline to stay on track.
Can we circle back to that later? I want to stick to the agenda.
That's a good point, let's discuss it after the meeting.
We can check that topic later.

cards.note:
**[17]**

The structure for not deviate is incorrect. To express purpose, use [to not deviate] or [so we don't deviate].

~Let's see that after~ is too simple and loses the professional context of managing a meeting's focus. Using idioms like [take it offline] or [circle back] shows more fluency.

cards.sideA: ¿Alguna otra pregunta antes de terminar?

sideB.text: Any other questions before we wrap up?
Does anyone have anything else before we go?
Are there any final questions?
Any other questions before finishing?

cards.note:
**[14]**

~Question~ should usually be plural ([questions]). After 'before', use the -ing form of the verb: [before finishing], not ~before to finish~.

~More questions~ sounds abrupt. Using [Any other questions] or [Any final questions] is more natural and polite.

cards.sideA: Les voy a compartir el enlace en el chat.

sideB.text: I'm sharing the link in the chat now.
I'll drop the link in the chat for you all.
The link is going into the chat.
I'm going to share the link in the chat.

cards.note:
The structure is [share something WITH someone]. ~I'm going to share you the link~ is incorrect.

'Compartir' does not translate to ~part~ in this context. The correct verb is [to share].

Both [I'm sharing...] (Present Continuous) and [I'm going to share...] are excellent for expressing an immediate future action in this context.

cards.sideA: Ya habiamos visto ese problema anteriormente.

sideB.text: We've seen this issue before.
This problem looks familiar; I think we've encountered it in the past.
This isn't a new issue for us.
We've already seen this issue.

cards.note:
**[5]**

The Present Perfect tense ([We've seen]) is ideal for talking about past experiences without a specific time. The simple past (We saw this issue before) is also correct but less common for this nuance.

~Beforely~ is not a word. Use [before] or [previously].

~We've been seen this issue before.~ (Incorrect verb structure. This mixes the active present perfect 'We have seen' with a passive form. The correct active form is [We've seen].)

~We've seen already this issue before.~ (This is redundant because 'already' and 'before' have similar meanings. Also, the word order is unnatural. The correct form is 'We've already seen this issue'.)

cards.sideA: Sí, es el mismo problema de antes, solo que con otra cuenta.

sideB.text: Yes, it's the same issue as before, just with a different account.
Right, that's the same problem, but it's happening on another account.
It's the same underlying issue, the only new variable is the account.

cards.note:
The phrase 'solo que' is idiomatically translated as [just with] or [but with].

~The only that~ is a literal and incorrect translation. A more natural way to say it is [the only difference is...].

~Yes, it's the same issue than before.~ (Incorrect preposition. The correct idiom is 'the same as...', not 'the same than...'.)

cards.sideA: Ese es un nuevo problema, ¿podríamos ver sus capturas de pantalla?

sideB.text: That's a new issue. Could we see your screenshots?
Okay, this looks like a new problem. Can you share the screenshots?
This is a new one. Would you be able to show us the screenshots for it?
That's a new issue. Could we see its screenshots?

cards.note:
The possessive adjective for a formal 'you' is [your]. Don't confuse it with their (de ellos).

~Screen captures~ is also correct, but [screenshots] (Noun) is far more common in a technical context.

Using [its] is also correct, but it changes the focus. [Your screenshots] refers to the screenshots you (the person) have. [Its screenshots] refers to the screenshots belonging to the issue itself. Both are valid.

cards.sideA: Son los mismos problemas que hemos visto en otras provincias.

sideB.text: These are the same issues we've seen in other regions.
It's the same set of problems we've observed in other environments.
We've run into these exact same issues in other areas.
They are the same issues we've seen in other provinces.

cards.note:
'Provincias' can translate to [regions], [areas], or even [environments] in a technical context, depending on the system's architecture.

~The sames problems~ is incorrect. [The same] is an adjective and does not become plural.

cards.sideA: Sí, ese problema es muy parecido al que ya hemos visto.

sideB.text: Yes, this problem is very similar to one we've seen before.
Right, this issue looks a lot like the one we've already encountered.
Yeah, this issue rings a bell; it's very close to the other one.
Yes, that issue is really similar to one we've seen before.

cards.note:
[Rings a bell] (Idiom) is a great informal way to say something sounds familiar.

~Very seem~ is incorrect. [Seem] is a verb. To say 'parecido', use adjectives like [similar to] or [like].

cards.sideA: Estos problemas son nuevos, ¿dónde puedo encontrar las capturas de pantalla?

sideB.text: These issues are new. Where can I find the screenshots?
Okay, these are new problems. Where are the screenshots located?
Since these are new issues, can you point me to where the screenshots are?

cards.note:
**[3]**

[To point someone to something] (Verb Phrase) means to show them where it is. It's a useful phrase for directing people.

~Where are located the screenshots?~ has incorrect word order for a question. The correct form is [Where are the screenshots located?].

cards.sideA: Creo que estos problemas ya están repetidos.

sideB.text: I think these issues are duplicates.
I believe these are repeated issues; we might have them logged already.
I have a feeling these problems have already been reported.
I think these issues are repeated.
I think these issues are already repeated.

cards.note:
[Duplicates] (Noun) or [duplicate issues] is the standard term in issue tracking systems.

[I think these issues are repeated] is a perfectly correct and common phrase. In a technical context like issue tracking, using the noun [duplicates] (e.g., 'these issues are duplicates') is often more concise and standard.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes darme acceso para revisar los logs?

sideB.text: Can you grant me access to check the logs?
Could you give me permission to look at the logs?
I need access to review the server logs.
Can you give me access to check the logs?

cards.note:
'Dar acceso' translates to [grant access] or [give permission].

~Give me access for check~ is incorrect. To express purpose, it's more natural to use the infinitive [to check], not the -ing form.

~Can you give me the grant...~ (Incorrect word choice. 'Grant' is a noun, but it's not the correct noun for 'permission' in this context. Use the verb [to grant] as in 'grant me access', or the noun [permission] as in 'give me permission'.)

cards.sideA: El fix está listo para ser probado en el ambiente de QA.

sideB.text: The fix is ready to be tested in the QA environment.
The fix is ready for testing in the QA environment.
We can now test the fix on the QA server.

cards.note:
**[12]**

The passive voice [to be tested] is very common. The structure ~for to be tested~ is incorrect.

`QA` (Abbreviation) stands for Quality Assurance. `Environment` and `server` are often used interchangeably in this context.

cards.sideA: Escalemos este problema al equipo senior.

sideB.text: Let's escalate this issue to the senior team.
We should escalate this problem to the senior developers.
This needs to be escalated to the senior team.
Let's bring this to the senior team.
We need to get the senior team involved in this.

cards.note:
The verb [escalate] (Verb) means to raise an issue to a higher level of authority or expertise.

The verb to scale means to change in size (e.g., scale a mountain, scale an application) and is incorrect here.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué provincias necesitan ese cambio?

sideB.text: Which provinces need that change?
What provinces require this change?
Which regions are affected by this change?

cards.note:
**[2]**

Both [Which] and [What] can be used here. [Which] is often preferred when choosing from a specific list of provinces, while [What] is more general.

In a business context, [provinces] can often be replaced with [regions] or [areas].

~What provinces needs...~ (Incorrect verb agreement. 'Provinces' is plural, so it requires the base verb [need], not 'needs'.)

~Wich provinces do they need that change?~ (Incorrect spelling of 'Which'. Also, the subject 'they' is not present in the original Spanish sentence.)

cards.sideA: ¿De qué provincia estás hablando?

sideB.text: Which province are you talking about?
What province are you referring to?
Which province do you mean?

cards.note:
**[50]**

In English questions, it is very common and natural to end the sentence with a preposition (e.g., 'talking about').

[Referring to] is a more formal alternative to [talking about].

~Of what province you are talking?~ (Incorrect word order. Questions require an auxiliary verb before the subject: '...are you talking?'.)

cards.sideA: ¿En qué provincias aplican esos cambios?

sideB.text: Which provinces do these changes apply to?
In which provinces are these changes applicable?
Which regions are covered by these changes?
Which provinces need these changes?

cards.note:
**[16]**

The phrasal verb [to apply to] is the most natural way to express that a rule or change affects something.

[Covered by] is a good synonym in this context.

~In what provinces apply these changes?~ (Incorrect question structure. You need the auxiliary verb 'do' before the subject: '...do these changes apply?') 

~Which provinces do apply these changes?~ (Incorrect word order. The auxiliary verb 'do' must come before the subject 'these changes'. The correct structure is 'Which provinces do these changes apply to?')

~Which provinces do these changes apply?~ (Incorrect. The phrasal verb is 'to apply to', so the preposition 'to' is required at the end of the sentence.)

'Which provinces need these changes?' is a valid sentence, but it focuses more on the *necessity* of the changes rather than simply where they are applied.

cards.sideA: Yo podría hacerlo, pero solo día por medio.

sideB.text: I could do it, but only every other day.
I'd be able to do it, but just on alternate days.
I can handle that, but only every second day.

cards.note:
**[92]**

The Spanish phrase 'día por medio' is idiomatically translated as [every other day] or [every second day]. [On alternate days] is a slightly more formal option.

~a day yes, a day no~ (This is a literal translation and not idiomatic. Use [every other day] instead.)

Be careful not to use [day by day], which means 'gradually over time' or 'daily'.

cards.sideA: Día por medio podría unirme.

sideB.text: I could join every other day.
I can make it every other day.
I'd be able to attend on alternate days.

cards.note:
[Every other day] is the most common and natural translation for 'día por medio'.

[I can make it] is a very common, informal phrase for 'I can attend' or 'I can join'.

~I could join day by day~ (Incorrect. 'Day by day' means something happens daily, which is the opposite of 'día por medio'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Este cambio aplica a todos los ambientes?

sideB.text: Does this change apply to all environments?
Does this modification affect every environment?
Does this change impact all environments?

cards.note:
**[3]**

The subject is [this change], which is singular (it). Therefore, the question requires the auxiliary [Does].

~Do this change apply...~ is incorrect because 'Do' is used for plural subjects (they, these changes) or for 'I/you/we'.

cards.sideA: ¿Por qué estos logs no contienen la información completa?

sideB.text: Why don't these logs contain the full information?
Why do these logs lack the complete data?
Why do these logs not have the complete information?

cards.note:
**[4]**

The subject here is [these logs], which is plural (they). The correct auxiliary verb is [do]. For a negative question, we use [don't] or [do not].

~Why doesn't these logs...~ is incorrect because 'doesn't' is for singular subjects.

cards.sideA: ¿Esa nueva política de seguridad impacta nuestro flujo de trabajo actual?

sideB.text: Does that new security policy impact our current workflow?
Does that new security policy affect our current workflow?
Does that new security policy have an effect on our current workflow?

cards.note:
**[3]**


The [complete subject] is 'that new security policy'. Since 'policy' is a singular noun, the correct auxiliary verb is [Does].

~Do that new security policy...~ is grammatically incorrect.

cards.sideA: ¿Esas credenciales funcionan en el ambiente de QA?

sideB.text: Do those credentials work in the QA environment?
Do those credentials grant access to the QA environment?
Are these credentials valid for the QA environment?

cards.note:
**[3]**


The subject is [those credentials], which is plural. Therefore, questions with action verbs must start with [Do]. For questions about state, using [Are] is also a natural and correct translation.

~Does those credentials work...~ is incorrect as 'Does' is for singular subjects.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué hace exactamente este botón en la interfaz?

sideB.text: What exactly does this button do on the interface?
What function does this button perform on the UI?
What action does this button trigger on the UI?

cards.note:
**[3]**

The subject is [this button] (singular 'it'), so we use [does]. In the first example, 'do' is used twice: first as an auxiliary ([does]) and second as the main verb ([do]).

~What this button does?~ is incorrect question structure. Inversion (auxiliary before subject) is required.

~What exactly does this button on the interface?~ (Incomplete question: The main verb 'do' is missing at the end.)

cards.sideA: ¿Dónde se guardan estos archivos de configuración?

sideB.text: Where are these configuration files stored?
Where do these configuration files get saved?
Where are these configuration files kept?
Where do these setting files get saved?

cards.note:
**[50]**

The Spanish 'se guardan' is a passive construction. This can be translated with the passive voice ([Where are... stored?]) or an active verb. For the active version, the subject is [these configuration files] (plural), so the auxiliary must be [do].

~Where does these files save?~ is incorrect because the subject 'files' is plural.

~Where do these configuration files can be saved?~ (Incorrect: Cannot use two auxiliary verbs, 'do' and 'can', together in a question. Use one or the other: 'Where can they be saved?' or 'Where do they get saved?'.)

~Where do these configuration files are saved?~ (Incorrect: Cannot mix the auxiliary 'do' with the verb 'to be' ('are') in this question format. Use 'Where are they saved?' (passive) or 'Where do you save them?' (active).)

~Where do these files be saved?~ (Incorrect verb form. After the auxiliary 'do', you must use the base form of the main verb, like 'get' or 'go'. You cannot use 'do' with 'be' in this structure. Correct options are 'Where are these files saved?' or 'Where do these files get saved?'.)

cards.sideA: ¿El último reporte de errores menciona este problema?

sideB.text: Does the latest bug report mention this issue?
Does the last error report include this problem?
Is this issue mentioned in the latest bug report?
Does the last bug report mention this issue?
Does the latest report mention this issue?

cards.note:
**[3]**


The [complete subject] is 'the latest bug report'. The core noun, 'report', is singular, so the question must use [Does]. A passive voice alternative ([Is this issue mentioned...]) is also very common and natural.

~Do the latest bug report...~ is a common error if one focuses on 'bugs' instead of 'report'.

~Does the last issue's report mention this issue?~ (Unnatural phrasing. 'Bug report' or 'error report' is the standard term, not 'issue's report'.)

~Does the lastest report mention this issue?~ (Typo: The correct superlative form of 'late' is 'latest'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Todos estos cambios necesitan aprobación del cliente?

sideB.text: Do all of these changes need client approval?
Do all these modifications require sign-off from the client?
Do all these changes depend on the client's approval?

cards.note:
**[3]**


The subject of the sentence is [All of these changes], which is plural. Therefore, the auxiliary verb [Do] is required.

[Sign-off] (Noun) is a very common term for formal approval in a business context. The verb is 'approve', but the noun is 'approval'. After 'need', you should use the noun.

~Do all of these changes need approve from the client?~ (Incorrect word form: 'Need' should be followed by a noun. 'Approve' is a verb; the correct noun is 'approval'.)

~All do these changes need client approval?~ (Incorrect question structure: The auxiliary verb 'Do' must come before the subject 'all these changes'.)

cards.sideA: ¿La documentación de este proyecto incluye los nuevos requerimientos?

sideB.text: Does this project's documentation include the new requirements?
Does the documentation for this project cover the new requirements?
Are the new requirements included in this project's documentation?
Does the documentation of this project include the new requirements?

cards.note:
**[20]**

The true subject here is [documentation], which is an uncountable (and therefore singular) noun. Active questions must use [Does]. A passive alternative ([Are the new requirements included...]) is also perfectly natural.

~Do this project's documentation...~ is a frequent mistake.

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo afectan estas limitaciones técnicas al cronograma?

sideB.text: How do these technical limitations affect the schedule?
How do these technical constraints impact the timeline?
In what way do these technical limitations influence the schedule?

cards.note:
**[3]**

The subject is [these technical limitations], a plural phrase. The question requires the auxiliary verb [do].

[Timeline] and [schedule] are synonyms. [Constraints] and [limitations] are also synonyms in this context.

cards.sideA: Todo al mismo tiempo, igual que la version web.

sideB.text: All at the same time, just like the web version.
Everything happens simultaneously, the same as the web version.
It all happens at once, just like on the web.

cards.note:
The phrase 'igual que' translates to [just like] or [the same as].

~The same that~ is a common error. The correct structure is [the same as].

[Simultaneously] and [at once] are excellent synonyms for 'at the same time'.

~Everything at the same time,...~ (Incorrect structure. The pronoun 'Everything' functions as the subject and requires a verb to form a complete sentence. Without a verb, it feels like an incomplete thought, leaving the listener wondering 'Everything... what?'. Correct form: [Everything happens at the same time...]

cards.sideA: ¿Debería ser todo al mismo tiempo, como en la versión web?

sideB.text: Should it be all at the same time, like in the web version?
Should everything happen at once, just like on the web?
Should it all be simultaneous, like the web version?

cards.note:
**[3]**

To form a question with a modal verb like 'should', the verb must come before the subject. Correct: [Should it be...?], not ~It should be...?~

'Como en' can be translated as [like in] or [like on], both are natural in this context.

cards.sideA: ¿Como es llamada esa opción en la base de datos?

sideB.text: What is that option called in the database?
What is that option named in the database?
What's the name for that option in the database?

cards.note:
**[3]**

When asking for a name, the correct question word in English is [What], not 'How'.

The most common and natural phrasing is [What is it called?] or [What is it named?]. A literal translation like 'How is it called?' is a very common mistake but is grammatically incorrect for this purpose.

cards.sideA: ¿Como es llamada esa acción en la interfaz principal?

sideB.text: What is that action called on the main interface?
What's that action referred to as on the main UI?
What is the name for that action on the main screen?
What is that action named in the main interface?

cards.note:
**[3]**

Always use [What is it called?] to ask for a name. Avoid the literal translation How is it called?.

'Interfaz principal' can be translated as [main interface], [main UI] (User Interface), or [main screen].

~How is that action named on the main interface?~ (Incorrect. To ask for a name, use 'What', not 'How'. 'How' asks about the method or process.)

cards.sideA: ¿No crees que esta solución es demasiado compleja?

sideB.text: Don't you think this solution is too complex?
Isn't this solution a bit over-engineered?
Do you not think this solution is overly complex?

cards.note:
**[4]**

Negative questions often start with a contracted auxiliary like [Don't] to confirm an opinion. The formal, less common version places 'not' after the subject: [Do you not think...].

Avoid double auxiliaries. ~Why do you don't think...~ is incorrect. The correct form is [Why don't you think...].

cards.sideA: ¿Esta nueva función no debería estar ya en producción?

sideB.text: Shouldn't this new feature be in production already?
Wasn't this new feature supposed to be live by now?
Should this new feature not be in production already?

cards.note:
**[4]**

For questions with modal verbs, form the negative by adding 'n't'. [Shouldn't] is the most common form for conversation. The formal structure is [Should... not...].

Do not add 'do' or 'does'. ~Does shouldn't this feature...~ is grammatically incorrect.

cards.sideA: ¿No habíamos solucionado este problema en el último release?

sideB.text: Didn't we fix this issue in the last release?
Didn't we already solve this problem in the previous release?
Did we not resolve this issue in the last release?
Haven't we fixed this issue in the latest release?
Haven't we solved this issue in the latest release?

cards.note:
**[4]**

For past tense negative questions, use [Didn't]. It's formed from 'did + not'. The question is structured as: [Didn't + subject + base verb].

Never mix past tense on the auxiliary and the main verb. Didn't we fixed... is incorrect. It must be [Didn't we fix...].

Using the Present Perfect ([Haven't we fixed...]) is also correct and emphasizes the connection of the past action to the present situation.

cards.sideA: ¿Por qué el sistema no está actualizando los datos?

sideB.text: Why isn't the system updating the data?
Why aren't the records being updated by the system?
For what reason is the system not updating the data?

cards.note:
**[4]**

When using question words like 'Why', the negative auxiliary ([isn't], [doesn't], etc.) comes right after it. [Why isn't the system...].

The subject must go between the auxiliary and the main verb. ~Why isn't updating the system...~ is incorrect word order.

cards.sideA: ¿No puedes replicar el error con la cuenta de prueba?

sideB.text: Can't you replicate the bug with the test account?
Aren't you able to reproduce the issue using the test account?
Are you not able to replicate the error with the test account?

cards.note:
**[4]**

With modal verbs like 'can', the negative question is formed with [Can't]. This is very common to express surprise or to check for an expected ability.

Do not add other auxiliaries. ~Do you can't replicate...~ is a frequent mistake. Just use [Can't you...].

cards.sideA: ¿Qué módulo causa este conflicto en el sistema?

sideB.text: What module causes this conflict in the system?
Which module is creating this system conflict?
What part of the system generates this conflict?

cards.note:
**[2]**

This is a **Subject Question**. The question phrase [What module] is the 'actor' performing the action ('causes'). Because we are asking about the subject, no auxiliary verb like 'do' or 'does' is needed. The main verb ('causes') is conjugated directly.

~What module does cause this conflict?~.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué módulo modificó el equipo de desarrollo?

sideB.text: What module did the development team modify?
Which module did the dev team change?
What module was modified by the development team?

cards.note:
**[3]**

This is an **Object Question**. We are asking about what received the action. The subject (the 'actor') is [the development team]. Since the subject is known, we MUST use the auxiliary verb 'did' to form the past tense question correctly.

~What module the development team modified?~.

cards.sideA: ¿Quién implementó esta función originalmente?

sideB.text: Who implemented this feature originally?
Who initially developed this functionality?
Who first built this feature?

cards.note:
**[2]**

This is a **Subject Question**. The question word [Who] is the subject we are looking for—the person who performed the action ('implemented'). Therefore, no auxiliary 'did' is used. The verb is placed directly after 'Who' in its past tense form.

~Who did implement this feature?~.

cards.sideA: ¿A quién reportó el error el equipo de QA?

sideB.text: Who did the QA team report the bug to?
To whom did the QA team report the error?
Who did the QA team notify about the bug?

cards.note:
**[3]**

This is an *Object Question*. The subject performing the action is [the QA team]. The question word 'Who' asks about the object—the person who received the report. Because the subject is known, the auxiliary verb [did] is mandatory.

~Who the QA team reported the bug to?~.

~Who was reported by the QA team?~ (This is a valid passive sentence, but it changes the meaning. It asks which person was the *subject* of the report, not who *received* the report. To ask who received it, you must use an active structure like 'Who did the team report to?')

~Who did the QA team report the issue?~ (Incomplete. When asking who received the report, you need the preposition 'to' at the end: 'Who did the QA team report the issue to?'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué impide el despliegue a producción?

sideB.text: What prevents the deployment to production?
What is blocking the production release?
What's stopping the deployment to production?
What stops the deployment to production?

cards.note:
**[2]**

This is a Subject Question. We are asking for the 'thing' that is performing the action of preventing. The question word [What] acts as the subject. Consequently, no auxiliary verb is needed, and the main verb ('prevents', 'stops') is conjugated in the third person singular.

What does prevent the deployment?.

~What stop the production release?~ (Incorrect. Since 'What' is the third-person singular subject of the sentence, the verb must be conjugated with an '-s': 'stops'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Qué cambios requiere la nueva política de seguridad?

sideB.text: What changes does the new security policy require?
What modifications does the new security policy need?
What changes are needed for the new security policy?

cards.note:
**[3]**

This is an *Object Question*. The subject is [the new security policy]. The question asks about the object ('What changes'). Since we have a known subject, we must use the auxiliary verb [does] (because 'policy' is singular) before the subject.

What changes the new security policy requires?.

~What changes require the new security policy?~ (Incorrect question structure. This sentence treats 'What changes' as the subject doing the action. However, the real subject is 'the new security policy' (singular), so you must use the auxiliary verb 'does' before it. Correct form: 'What changes does the new security policy require?'.)

~What changes does the new security policy require to?~ (Incorrect. The verb 'require' in this question does not need 'to' at the end. You might be thinking of the structure 'require someone **to do** something', e.g., 'It requires us **to update** our software.')

cards.sideA: ¿Qué equipo tiene la versión más reciente del código?

sideB.text: Which team has the latest version of the code?
What team possesses the most recent codebase?
Which team holds the newest version of the code?

cards.note:
**[2]**

This is a **Subject Question**. The question phrase [Which team] is the subject we are asking about. It's the 'actor' that performs the action of 'having'. The main verb ('has') is used directly without an auxiliary. Note that 'have' becomes 'has' for the third-person singular.

~Which team does have the latest version?~.

cards.sideA: Yo iba a hacerlo, pero lo olvidé.

sideB.text: I was going to do it, but I forgot.
I was planning to do it, but it slipped my mind.

cards.note:
**[91]**

[Slipped my mind] is a common idiom that means 'I forgot'.

~I was going to do it, but I have forgotten.~ (Incorrect. When sequencing two past events like this, use the simple past for both actions: '...but I forgot'.)

cards.sideA: Iba a decírtelo, pero no fue necesario.

sideB.text: I was going to tell you, but it wasn't necessary.
I was about to tell you, but there was no need.

cards.note:
**[91]**

[I was about to] implies the action was very imminent. [There was no need] is a good alternative for 'it wasn't necessary'.

~I was for tell you...~ (Incorrect. The correct structure to express a recent past intention is [was/were going to] or [was/were about to].)

cards.sideA: Iba a escribirlo, pero no supe dónde.

sideB.text: I was going to write it down, but I didn't know where.
I intended to write it, but I couldn't figure out where.
I was going to write it, but I didn't know where.

cards.note:
**[91]**

[Write it down] is a separable phrasal verb. [To figure out] means to understand or solve something.

~I was going to write down it.~ (Incorrect. When the object of a separable phrasal verb is a pronoun like 'it' or 'them', it **must** go between the verb and the particle: [write it down].)

While 'write it' is grammatically correct, 'write it down' is more specific and common for taking notes, implying the action of recording information.

cards.sideA: El volumen está por sobre el mínimo.

sideB.text: The volume is above the minimum.
The volume is over the minimum threshold.

cards.note:
To indicate a level that is higher than another, use the prepositions [above] or [over].

~The volume is up the minimum.~ (Incorrect. 'Up' is not used in this context to compare levels.)

[Threshold] is a noun that means a level or point at which something starts to happen. In this context, it's a synonym for 'minimum level' or 'limit'.

cards.sideA: El volumen está por debajo del mínimo.

sideB.text: The volume is below the minimum.
The volume is under the minimum threshold.

cards.note:
To express that a level is lower than another, the correct prepositions are [below] or [under].

~The volume is down the minimum.~ (Incorrect. 'Down' is not used for comparing levels in this way.)

[Threshold] refers to a level or point at which something starts to happen or take effect.

cards.sideA: ¿De cuál estamos hablando específicamente?

sideB.text: Which one are we talking about here?
Could you specify which one you're referring to?
Which one do you mean, exactly?
Which specific one are we discussing?
Which one are we talking about specifically?

cards.note:
Use [Which] when choosing from a limited or known set of options. [What] is more general but can also be used.

It's very common for English questions to end with a preposition like [about] or [to].

~Of which one are you talking?~ is grammatically correct but overly formal and less common in conversation.

cards.sideA: Entonces, solo lo ves al final, ¿cierto?

sideB.text: So you only see it at the end, right?
So it only shows up at the very end, correct?
Just to be clear, you don't see it until the final step?
So it's not visible until the very last step, is that right?

cards.note:
Tag questions like [right?], [correct?], or [is that right?] are perfect for confirming information.

The phrasal verb [to show up] means 'to appear'.

~..., no?~ or ~..., true?~ are direct translations from Spanish but are not natural English tag questions in this context.

cards.sideA: Espera un segundo.

sideB.text: Hold on a second.
Just a moment.
Hang on a sec.
Give me a second.

cards.note:
[Hold on] and [Hang on] are common phrasal verbs for asking someone to wait. [Sec] is an informal shortening of 'second'.

~Wait me a second.~ is incorrect. You can say [Wait a second] or [Wait for me].

cards.sideA: ¿Tienes una captura de pantalla de eso?

sideB.text: Do you have a screenshot of it?
Can you grab a screenshot of that for me?
Could you send over a screenshot?
Would you be able to get a screenshot of that?

cards.note:
[Screenshot] is the most common term. While screen capture is understandable, it's less frequent in daily conversation.

~You have a screenshot?~ is a statement, not a question. Questions must start with an auxiliary verb like [Do] or [Can].

In this context, 'it' and 'that' are interchangeable: 'Do you have a screenshot of it?' and 'Do you have a screenshot of that?' are both correct.

cards.sideA: Está bien. Puedes enviarlo más tarde.

sideB.text: That's fine. You can send it later.
No problem. Feel free to send it over later.
It's okay, you can get it to me when you have a chance.
There's no rush, you can send it later.

cards.note:
[When you have a chance] is a polite idiom for 'when you have time'. [No rush] is a common way to say something is not urgent.

~Is good~ is an incorrect translation of 'Está bien' in this context. Use [That's fine] or [It's okay].

cards.sideA: ¿Estás usando la versión nueva o la antigua?

sideB.text: Are you using the new one or the old one?
Are you on the new version or the old one?
Is that with the latest version or a previous one?
Which version are you running?

cards.note:
Using the preposition [on] as in [Are you on the new version?] is very common in a software context.

[Latest] is a synonym for 'newest'.

~You are using...?~ is incorrect question structure. The verb 'to be' ([Are]) must come before the subject ([you]).

cards.sideA: Vamos a revisar esto y te daremos una respuesta.

sideB.text: We're going to review this and get back to you.
We'll look into this and follow up with you.
Let us check this out, and we'll let you know what we find.
We'll investigate this and report back.
We're going to check this and give you an answer.

cards.note:
Phrasal verbs are very common here: [get back to someone], [look into something], [check something out], and [follow up with someone].

~We will return you with an answer~ is an incorrect and unnatural structure. The verb 'return' is not used this way.

['To give someone an answer'] is correct and direct. Phrasal verbs like [get back to you] are often preferred in professional contexts as they can sound slightly softer.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes repetirme eso una vez más?

sideB.text: Can you run that by me one more time?
Could you say that again, please?
Sorry, could you repeat that?
I didn't quite catch that, could you repeat it?
Could you repeat that one more time, please?

cards.note:
[To run something by someone] is a common idiom that means to tell someone something so they can give their opinion. It's used here as a casual way to ask for repetition.

[I didn't catch that] is another idiom meaning 'I didn't hear or understand'.

cards.sideA: Entendido. ¿Cuál es el siguiente paso?

sideB.text: Got it. What's the next step?
Okay, I understand. What's next?
Understood. What should we do now?
Alright. Where do we go from here?
Okay, I got it. What's the next step?

cards.note:
[Got it] is a very common and efficient way to confirm understanding. [Where do we go from here?] is a great idiom for asking about the next steps.

Using the past tense, I understood, is less common for immediate confirmation than the present tense [I understand] or the short form [Got it].

cards.sideA: ¿Hay alguna novedad sobre ese problema?

sideB.text: Any updates on that issue?
Is there any news on that problem?
What's the latest on that issue?
What's the status of that issue?

cards.note:
In questions like this, you can often omit the verb 'to be' for conciseness: [Any updates?] is a shortening of [Are there any updates?].

[What's the latest] is a common informal phrase for asking about the most recent information.

~Is there a new on that problem?~ ('News' is an uncountable noun and does not use the article 'a'. The correct form is 'Is there any news...?')

~Is there any updates on that issue?~ ('Updates' is a plural noun and requires 'Are there...'. The correct form is 'Are there any updates...?')

cards.sideA: OK, eso no debería estar pasando.

sideB.text: Okay, that shouldn't be happening.
Right, that's definitely not supposed to happen.
Okay, that's not the expected behavior.
I see. That's certainly not right.

cards.note:
[Shouldn't] is the contraction of 'should not' and is used to express that something is wrong or unexpected.

[To be supposed to do something] is a very common structure to talk about what is expected.

~That no should be happening~ is incorrect word order for a negative statement.

~Okay, that shouldn't be happened.~ (Incorrect verb form. After a modal verb + 'be' (like 'should be'), you use the -ing form for a continuous action. The verb 'happen' is intransitive, so it cannot be used in the passive voice here. The correct form is 'happening'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Es un problema nuevo o ya había ocurrido antes?

sideB.text: Is this a new issue or has it happened before?
Is this a recent problem, or is it a recurring one?
Have you seen this issue before, or is this the first time?
Is this a known issue?

cards.note:
[Recurring] means something that happens again and again. [A known issue] is a standard term in tech for a problem that has been reported previously.

~Is this a new issue or it happened before?~ (This structure is grammatically awkward. When you connect two clauses with 'or' to form a single question, both should follow a question structure. The second part, 'it happened before', is a statement. The correct form, 'Is this a new issue or has it happened before?', connects two parallel questions: 'Is this...?' and 'Has it...?'. Using the Present Perfect ('has it happened') is also better because it asks about any time in the past leading up to now, which fits the context.)

cards.sideA: Déjame revisar eso por mi lado.

sideB.text: Let me check that on my end.
I'll take a look at that from my side.
Let me just verify that over here.
I'll investigate that from my end.
Let me check that on my side.

cards.note:
[On my end] and [from my side] are common idioms that mean 'from my perspective' or 'using my own resources'.

~Let me to check that~ is incorrect. After 'let me', always use the base form of the verb without 'to': [Let me check].

~Let me check that on my own.~ (This is grammatically correct, but has a different meaning. 'On my own' means 'alone/without help', while 'on my end/side' means 'from my perspective or area of responsibility'.)

cards.sideA: Hagamos seguimiento de esto por correo.

sideB.text: Let's follow up on this by email.
Let's continue this conversation over email.
How about we handle this through email?
Let's take this offline and discuss it via email.
Let's continue this by email.

cards.note:
[To follow up on] something is a key phrasal verb meaning to continue with it later.

[Take this offline] is a very common business idiom that means to discuss a topic outside of the current meeting, often with a smaller group.

cards.sideA: Solo para confirmar, ¿cuál es la prioridad aquí?

sideB.text: Just to confirm, what's the priority here?
Just so I'm clear, how high of a priority is this?
To make sure we're aligned, what's the priority level for this?
How urgent is this?
Just to be sure, what's the priority here?

cards.note:
[Just so I'm clear] and [To make sure we're aligned] are excellent professional phrases for introducing a clarifying question.

[Urgent] is a great synonym for 'high priority'.

~Which is the priority?~ is less natural than [What is the priority?] when asking about the nature of something.

[Just to be sure] is a great alternative to 'Just to confirm'.

cards.sideA: ¿No deberíamos priorizar este bug antes del próximo despliegue?

sideB.text: Shouldn't we prioritize this bug before the next deployment?
Shouldn't this bug take priority over the next release?
Don't you think this bug should be a higher priority?

cards.note:
**[4]**

[Shouldn't] is used to suggest a course of action or confirm an expectation. It's a polite way to introduce a strong suggestion.

Be careful not to mix auxiliaries. A common error is ~Does shouldn't we prioritize...~; the modal [shouldn't] stands alone at the beginning of the question.

cards.sideA: ¿No debería la documentación incluir los criterios de aceptación?

sideB.text: Shouldn't the documentation include the acceptance criteria?
Aren't the acceptance criteria supposed to be in the documentation?
Shouldn't the acceptance criteria be part of the documentation?

cards.note:
**[4]**

The structure is [Shouldn't] + [Subject] + [Base Verb]. The main verb always stays in its base form (e.g., [include]) and does not take an '-s'.

A common error is conjugating the main verb: ~Shouldn't the documentation includes...~ is incorrect.

cards.sideA: ¿No deberíamos haber informado al cliente sobre este retraso?

sideB.text: Shouldn't we have informed the client about this delay?
Shouldn't we have let the client know about this delay?
Should we not have told the client about this delay?

cards.note:
**[4]**

To talk about a past action that was expected but didn't happen, use the structure: [Shouldn't] + [have] + [Past Participle].

A frequent mistake is using 'had' instead of 'have': ~Shouldn't we had informed...~ is incorrect. The auxiliary is always [have].

~Shouldn't we have to informe to the client about this delay?~ (Incorrect. The structure for a past missed action is 'should have + past participle', not 'have to'. Also, the verb 'inform' does not take 'to' before the object: you 'inform someone'.)

cards.sideA: ¿No es este el comportamiento esperado para esa funcionalidad?

sideB.text: Isn't this the expected behavior for that feature?
Isn't this how the feature is supposed to work?
Is this not the expected behavior for that functionality?

cards.note:
**[4]**

[Isn't] is used to confirm a present state or fact you believe is true. It shows you have an expectation and are surprised by what you are seeing.

Avoid subject-verb agreement errors with complex subjects. The subject here is [this], which is singular. ~Aren't this behavior...~ is incorrect.

cards.sideA: ¿No es esa la misma issue que reportamos la semana pasada?

sideB.text: Isn't that the same issue we reported last week?
Isn't this a duplicate of the issue we logged last week?
Isn't that the same bug from last week?

cards.note:
**[4]**

[Isn't] is used for singular subjects like 'that' or 'this'. Using technical terms like [duplicate] or [logged] instead of 'reported' is very common in meetings.

A common error is using an unnecessary article with time expressions: ~...reported the last week?~ is incorrect. The correct form is just [last week].

~Isn't that the same issue we've reported last week?~ (Incorrect. The Present Perfect tense ('we've reported') cannot be used with a specific past time marker like 'last week'. The Simple Past ('we reported') must be used instead.)

cards.sideA: ¿Tienes las cuentas que has usado para testearlo?

sideB.text: Do you have the accounts you've used to test it?
Can you share the accounts you used for testing?
Could you provide the accounts you've been using for testing?

cards.note:
The Spanish question can be formed just with intonation, but in English, you must use an auxiliary verb. The statement [You have the accounts...] becomes a question by adding [Do] at the beginning: [Do you have...].

~You have the accounts...?~ is a common error as it is a statement, not a question.

To express purpose, use the infinitive [to test], not ~for test~ or ~for testing it~.

cards.sideA: ¿Cuánto tiempo va a durar la reunión?

sideB.text: How long is the meeting going to last?
How long will the meeting be?
How long will the meeting take?
What's the duration of the meeting?
How long will the meeting last?

cards.note:
**[102]**

To ask about duration, you can use verbs like [last], [be], or [take].

The noun [duration] is also correct but often sounds more formal.

A common error is using the noun 'duration' as a verb: ~How long will the meeting duration?~ is incorrect.

cards.sideA: La tarea no debería tomar más de dos horas.

sideB.text: The task shouldn't take more than two hours.
The task shouldn't last longer than two hours.
This task has a maximum duration of two hours.

cards.note:
**[102]**

[Shouldn't take] is a very common way to estimate the maximum time required for something.

[Longer than] is the correct comparative form. A common error is mixing prepositions: ~last more of two hours~ is incorrect. Use [last longer than] or [take more than].

cards.sideA: No interrumpas al cliente durante la demostración.

sideB.text: Don't interrupt the client during the demo.
Let's hold all questions until after the demo.
Please wait until the demonstration is over to ask questions.

cards.note:
**[102]**

Use [during] to specify *when* something happens, followed by a noun for the event ([the demo]).

The common error is to use 'for': ~Don't interrupt for the demo~ is incorrect as 'for' is used to state a length of time (e.g., 'for ten minutes').

cards.sideA: Estuve en una llamada por casi una hora.

sideB.text: I was on a call for almost an hour.
The call lasted for nearly an hour.
I was busy on a call for the better part of an hour.

cards.note:
**[102]**

Use [for] to state the length or quantity of time ([for an hour]).

Contrast this with 'during'. A common mistake is to say ~I was on a call during an hour~. This is incorrect because 'an hour' is a quantity of time, not a named event.

cards.sideA: La última interrupción del servicio duró tres horas.

sideB.text: The last service outage lasted for three hours.
The service was down for three hours.
The duration of the last outage was three hours.
The last service interruption lasted for three hours.
The last interruption of the service lasted three hours.

cards.note:
**[102]**

Both [lasted for] and [was down for] are natural ways to express the duration of a past event.

Using [duration] is more formal and suitable for reports.

A common redundancy error is mixing verb forms: ~The outage was lasted for three hours~. The correct forms are [The outage lasted] or [The outage was three hours long].

'Service interruption' is a common compound noun and often sounds more natural than 'interruption of the service'. The preposition 'for' is optional when talking about duration (e.g., 'lasted three hours').

cards.sideA: ¿Cómo se activa este modo?

sideB.text: How does this mode get activated?
How is this mode activated?
How do you activate this mode?

cards.note:
**[50]**

The structure for this question is: `How` + `auxiliary` + `subject` + `verb`. For a singular subject like [this mode], the auxiliary is [does].

Common errors include mixing auxiliaries (~How does this mode is activated?~) or incorrect verb conjugation (~How does this mode gets activated?~). After 'does', the verb must be in its base form ([get]).

~How does this mode activated?~ (Incorrect. After the auxiliary 'does', the main verb must be in its base form. The correct structure is 'How does this mode get activated?'.)

cards.sideA: ¿Cuándo se eliminan estos archivos temporales?

sideB.text: When do these temporary files get deleted?
When are these temporary files deleted?
When does the system delete these temporary files?

cards.note:
**[50]**

For a plural subject like [these temporary files], the correct auxiliary verb is [do].

A common mistake is to use 'does' with a plural subject (~When does these files get deleted?~). Another error is mixing auxiliaries: ~When do these files are deleted?~ is incorrect.

cards.sideA: ¿Por qué se canceló la reunión?

sideB.text: Why did the meeting get canceled?
Why was the meeting canceled?
Why did they cancel the meeting?

cards.note:
**[50]**

For questions in the simple past, the auxiliary is [did]. The main verb that follows must return to its base form ([get]).

Frequent errors involve mixing past tense auxiliaries (~Why did the meeting was canceled?~) or forgetting the auxiliary entirely (~Why the meeting get canceled?~).

~Why the meeting was canceled?~ (Incorrect word order for a direct question. The auxiliary verb 'was' should come before the subject 'the meeting': 'Why was the meeting canceled?'.)

cards.sideA: No estoy seguro de la respuesta, pero puedo investigarlo.

sideB.text: I'm not sure of the answer, but I can look into it.
I don't know off the top of my head, but I'll find out.
I'm not certain, but I can look it up.
I'll have to double-check on that and get back to you.

cards.note:
**[16]**

This shows different phrasal verbs for promising to find information. [Look into it] means to investigate. [Find out] means to discover. [Look it up] means to search a reference (like Google or docs).

With separable phrasal verbs like 'look up', a pronoun object like 'it' must go in the middle: [I can look it up]. A common error is placing it at the end: ~I can look up it.~

cards.sideA: Actualmente no sé cómo hacer eso, pero puedo aprenderlo.

sideB.text: I don't currently know how to do that, but I can learn.
I'm not familiar with that process, but I'm a quick learner.
I haven't done that before, but I can figure it out.
That's not something I'm familiar with, but I'm happy to learn.
Currently I don't know how to do that, but I can learn it.

cards.note:
**[16]**

Phrases like [I'm a quick learner] or [I can figure it out] are proactive and positive ways to address a knowledge gap in a professional setting.

The phrasal verb 'figure out' means to understand or solve something.

To talk about learning a skill, the correct structure is `learn how to do something`. A common error is using an incorrect preposition: ~I can learn about to do that.~

cards.sideA: ¿Qué hace exactamente este script?

sideB.text: What exactly does this script do?
What is the function of this script?
What does this script accomplish?

cards.note:
**[50]**

This structure uses 'does' as the auxiliary verb for a singular subject ([this script]) and 'do' as the main verb. The pattern is `What does + [subject] + do?`.

A very common error is omitting the main verb 'do' at the end of the question, which leaves the sentence incomplete: ~What exactly does this script?~.

cards.sideA: ¿Qué hizo el último hotfix para solucionar el problema?

sideB.text: What did the last hotfix do to solve the issue?
How did the last hotfix address the problem?
What action did the last hotfix take to fix the bug?

cards.note:
**[50]**

For questions in the simple past, the auxiliary is [did]. The main verb that follows must return to its base form ([do]).

A frequent error involves conjugating the main verb to the past tense as well, which is redundant: ~What did the last hotfix did to solve the issue?~.

cards.sideA: ¿La función hizo lo que esperábamos?

sideB.text: Did the function do what we expected?
Did the function perform as expected?
Did the function do its job correctly?

cards.note:
**[50]**

To form a yes/no question in the simple past, you must start with the auxiliary [Did], followed by the subject and the base form of the main verb ([do]). The structure is `Did + [subject] + do...?`.

A common mistake is to use the word order of a statement instead of a question: ~The function did what we expected?~.
